title: Considerations On Cost Disease
summary:
Key ideas:
- The cost of education, college, healthcare, infrastructure, and housing has significantly increased over the past 50 years, even after adjusting for inflation.
- The increase in costs is especially strange because improving technology and globalization are expected to cut costs, not increase them.
- People now have access to many opportunities that were formerly unavailable, yet the price is still much higher than before.
- Many of these services have also decreased in quality as an attempt to decrease costs even further.
- Tech improvements in one sector may push up prices in another sector.
- Health care and education costs have increased significantly over time but employee salaries have not risen much.
- Indirect government intervention through regulation may partly account for rising costs in health care and education.
- More caution and increased risk tolerance of institutions could be responsible for the increasing costs.
- The cost, in real terms, of important industries such as healthcare or education, has increased drastically over the years.
- The price increases are not matched with equivalent increases in quality and efficiency.
- The result is a generation with stagnant or declining living standards, due to the inability to keep up with the increased cost of basic human needs.
- Politics debates often revolve around how to mitigate the distribution of the losses, instead of addressing the central issue of cost increase.

Key learnings:
- The cost disease refers to increasing costs in general rather than a specific theory of why costs are increasing.
- The cost disease has been experienced in various sectors such as education, college, healthcare, infrastructure, and housing.
- Rising costs in one sector may have a ripple effect on others, even those less susceptible to tech improvements.
- Increased costs in health care and education sectors could be due to regulations and institutions' approach to risk tolerance.
- It is possible to provide the same quality of service at a fraction of the cost; hence, there is a need to scrutinize the cause of the increasing expenses.
- Ensuring universal access to healthcare or education would solve social problems but contribute to locking in the high prices of these industries.
- Political debates on issues such as taxation may mask the central problem of increased costs of basic human needs.
- The greatest anti-poverty advance would be creating a program that provides efficient healthcare, affordable education, and housing decreases.

Key questions:
- Do people understand that the cost disease exists, and the extent to which it has affected different sectors?
- Would poor and middle-class people rather get modern healthcare, education, and housing or the same as their parent's generation with modern technology and receive extra money?
- How many times more expensive would it be to receive the same quality of service in modern times without the gains from modern technology and globalization?
- How can we balance regulations in the education and health care sectors to avoid rising costs?
- What should be the appropriate approach to risk tolerance when it comes to institutions providing services in health care and education?
- Might institutions become increasingly risk-averse and institutionalized, with a lower risk tolerance over time?
- Might total compensation be increasing despite stagnant wages?
- Why are college tuitions incomparably high and why aren't people starting more colleges?
- Has the cost of human needs risen faster than wages have increased, and if so, why?
